channel.title: All Posts on Walker Harrison
channel.description: Recent content in All Posts on Walker Harrison

item.title: Grid Search: Finding the Most Convenient Block to Live on in New York City
item.description: They say you can find anything in New York, but can you find anything on a single block without crossing the street?

item.title: Is every Run Random? Investigating Momentum and Streaky Scoring in NBA Basketball
item.description: NBA players often refer to their sport as a “game of runs,” but is there anything to that term beyond describing a simple random process?

item.title: I've Got The Receipts! Sifting Through My Own Personal iMessage History
item.description: Discovering that five years’ worth of text messages were sitting on my MacBook allowed me to profile myself as a communicator and track the changes in my personal network.

item.title: Evaluating the NBA point spreads produced by FiveThirtyEight's RAPTOR metric
item.description: FiveThirtyEight posts win probabilities and point spreads for every NBA game based on RAPTOR, their home-brewed player value metric. Are they any good?

item.title: Abolish Overtime! An Argument in Favor of More Ties in the NFL
item.description: As unappealing as ties are to the average American sports fan, creating more of them in the NFL by eliminating the overtime period has a handful of advantages.

item.title: Who's the Funny One? Analyzing 7 Years of Messages from my College GroupMe
item.description: A group of nine friends and I have sent over 100,000 messages on GroupMe in the last seven years. Such a sizable corpus gives us a chance to figure out when the chat is most active, who receives and gets the most likes, and what unique terms define each participant.

item.title: Unraveling NFL Win Probability Graphs to Find the Best Games
item.description: How do you determine how good a game is from its win probability graph? You could compute the Excitement Index by adding up all the changes, or you could take a visual approach and “pull” all the slack out of the chart.

item.title: Stop Taking L's When Walking to Your Destination
item.description: We’re often directed to get from one point in a grid to another by taking a single turn and otherwise walking in two long segments. But the Walk/Don’t Walk signs that dictate our travel make this approach very inefficent, and motivate a better strategy that may save you a few minutes.

item.title: Estimating When CitiBike Rolled Out E-Bikes Using Change Point Detection
item.description: If electric bikes allow their riders to travel at greater speeds, will there be a corresponding dip in average trip duration between bikeshare docks that we can find in the data? We try to answer that question by applying a change point model to a notoriously difficult uphill route.

item.title: Visualizing How a Kernel Draws a Smooth Line
item.description: How does software like Excel or R trace a smooth line through a series of points? It’s easier to understand by visualizing how new values are created as a weighted mean of the existing data.

item.title: Gradient Ascent: Finding Uphill Routes for my Long Walks
item.description: An old back injury makes it so that walking uphill is much more comfortable for me than walking downhill. A programmatic search for uphill routes reveals how strict constraints and “greedy” decisions can lead to sub-optimal results.

item.title: Avoiding Variance on my Morning Commute
item.description: Sacrificing value for certainty is a common tradeoff in life. Is this what I was (accidentally) doing when I started walking the first part of my daily commute instead of taking the subway? Some historical MTA data can help answer that question.

item.title: Pushing Google's Autocorrect to the Limit
item.description: Everyone makes errors sometimes when hastily typing a query into a search bar, and most of the time Google is able to recognize your mistake and offer a suggestion. But what is this algorithm’s breaking point? How badly can you mis-type a word before even Google doesn’t know what you mean anymore?
